coachInfo.name: Dr. Dennis Tirch
coachInfo.title: The Founder of The Center for Compassion Focused Therapy

description:
Drawing on 20 years of research and centuries of meditation traditions, this program will give you all of the tools and knowledge you need to begin to take your life back from anxiety, worry and fear. You will learn how to open your heart and free your mind.

The state of the art of psychological science continues to show us how training the brain in mindfulness, acceptance and self-compassion, using evidence-based techniques, can allow us to release anxiety and step forward to reclaim our lives and our world.
marketingDescription:
All over the world, people are reporting struggles with anxiety, worry and fear at record levels. We are living with unprecedented stress, and many of us can’t find an effective way to deal with it.

Even though your anxious thoughts and feelings might seem out of control or disabling, you have a path to a better life available to you, and it involves the power of loving-kindness, self-compassion and a secret courage you were born to embody.

Drawing on 20 years of research and centuries of meditation traditions, this program will give you all of the tools and knowledge you need to begin to take your life back from anxiety, worry and fear. You will learn how to open your heart and free your mind.

The state of the art of psychological science continues to show us how training the brain in mindfulness, acceptance and self-compassion, using evidence-based techniques, can allow us to release anxiety and step forward to reclaim our lives and our world.

This program is taught by Dr. Dennis Tirch, an internationally recognized leader in the behavioral science of self-compassion, author of 6 books, Buddhist meditation teacher, social media presence, and founder of The Center for Compassion Focused Therapy in New York.

In this program, you will work with Dr. Tirch as you would a close friend, gradually learning how to free yourself from the grip of anxiety, worry and fear. Step by step, you will grasp the basics of mindfulness, acceptance and self-compassion training, and move towards mastery of how to open your heart and free your mind.

The methods and techniques in this program are drawn from Compassion Focused Therapy, Acceptance and Commitment Therapy and Buddhist Psychology, all supported by scientific research.

If you are struggling with anxiety problems, are a mental health practitioner, a student, or if you would just like to learn how to better free yourself from your fears to live a life worth loving, this program is meant for you.
objectiveGoals:
• Open your heart and free your mind: You will learn how the science of mindfulness, acceptance and compassion can lead you to greater courage, psychological flexibility and freedom from fear.
  • Cultivating present moment focused sensitivity – You will learn how mindful awareness and concentrated focus lead to liberation
  • Losing ourselves in love – You will learn how we can shift perspective out of our small, threat focused, and ego driven programming to deepen our observing mind, and get unstuck from anxiety, worry and fear in the process
  • What love can bear – You will learn how we can use self-compassion and willingness to better accept frightening feelings and tolerate distress.
  • Freeing the mind from our stories – You will learn how we can dis-identify with the inner monologues, stories, worries and imaginary catastrophes that show up with anxiety, worry and fear. With practice you can master this new approach to liberation from anxious and self-critical thinking, seeing through the illusions and stories that your mind weaves, while having the wisdom to see reality with a new clarity.
  • Opening your heart to what matters most – You will learn a program of values, authorship and emotional deepening techniques, all designed to help you establish personal aims that lead to a life of meaning, purpose and vitality. You can use this new roadmap for a purpose-driven life to live in a way that is less pushed by anxiety and more pulled by the promise of personal realization.
  • Walking the path with confidence and strength – You will learn state of the art behavior change and personal management techniques to consistently dedicate yourself to committed action, opening your heart, freeing your mind, and living a life worth loving.
name: Free Your Mind, Reclaim Your Life, Releasing Anxiety with Mindfulness, Acceptance and Self-Compassion
shortDescription: In this program, you will work with Dr. Tirch as you would a close friend, gradually learning how to free yourself from the grip of anxiety, worry and fear. Step by step, you will grasp the basics of mindfulness, acceptance and self-compassion training, and move towards mastery of how to open your heart and free your mind.

description: Pain happens, but suffering is created. We often find ourselves feeling stuck, overwhelmed, or maybe even at a loss of how we feel, because yet again, we have arrived at that familiar place of ruminating self-doubt or self-defeating behaviors. Our emotional states greatly impact our daily habits, productivity, and relationships.
marketingDescription:
Pain happens, but suffering is created. We often find ourselves feeling stuck, overwhelmed, or maybe even at a loss of how we feel, because yet again, we have arrived at that familiar place of ruminating self-doubt or self-defeating behaviors. Our emotional states greatly impact our daily habits, productivity, and relationships. 

This is a 10 week skills-based group to help individuals improve their emotional resiliency by breaking away from old, unhelpful patterns of thinking and doing to unearth the best version of themselves. The skills taught in this group are taken and heavily influenced from DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy) including mindfulness, emotion regulation, distress tolerance and interpersonal skills

Individuals will learn to develop a comprehensive toolbox of coping skills to avoid suffering, increase distress tolerance, increase self-compassion and self-worth, improve ability to effectively communicate your feelings and needs with others, and improve their overall quality of life by utilizing untapped inner skills and strengths. 

This group is not intended to replace or follow a traditional DBT group or program. The purpose of this program is to allow you to gain access to learning valuable life skills based on DBT, which can help you learn to manage your emotions and improve your quality of life.

Please note this group is psycho-educational and not clinical in nature. Participation in this online program does not mean participation in clinical psychotherapy.
objectiveGoals:
• Develop and/or broaden an extensive toolbox of coping to manage anxiety, low motivation, unhealthy habits, and interpersonal distress
  • Identify connection between unhelpful thinking and behaviors patterns to learn ways to manage self-doubt and avoid self-defeating behaviors
  • Learn ways to incorporate cognitive strategies to boost resiliency and restore a sense of well being
  • Improve emotional intelligence by learning to label, validate, and appreciate your emotions
  • Increase distress tolerance to improve emotion regulation and cope with life stressors
  • Learn effective communication skills to be able to advocate and express your needs, while establish and maintaining healthy relationships 
  • Increase knowledge on the impact of stress on physical/mental health to avoid maladaptive behaviors, decrease emotional vulnerability, and develop healthy habits
  • Learn strategies to get out of a crisis moment without increasing suffering

description:
Getting triggered is one of the unfortunate by products of life. This course explores a radically positive approach, based on cutting edge integration of attachment theory, trauma treatment and wisdom traditions to Resolving Triggers. The course is designed to provide teaching as well as experiential growth through practices and discussion.

This is not a clinical program, and it is not psychotherapy. Rather, lessons in this program are presented in the format of a psycho-educational format, integrating self-reflection and practice to increase awareness of the topic as well as ways to pivot when triggered by life circumstances.
marketingDescription:
When something in the here & now happens the neurons and synapses in the brain instantaneously find things in the past to correspond to.  That material (collection of thoughts, feelings, sensations, or memories) surges up and we “remember” stuff from the past.  When something in the moment corresponds to something in the past that was unpleasant, horrible, disturbing, frightening, repulsive, we call that being triggered. 

Whatever in the moment is triggering something from one of those time capsules, those time capsules explode with the experience exactly as it was encoded That’s the key thing here.  Whatever is held in that time capsule is loaded exactly as you were experiencing it back then.   When it’s good things it feels nice to remember it, we like it, and the time boundary is maintained. 

If however, and this is where the mind is absolutely amazing, if it was something that we didn’t like, didn’t want, the mind has all kinds of ways to shut out, cordon off the material so that we don’t have to deal with it.  It gets put aside, psychologically undigested, in one of these time capsules. 

Getting triggered is one of the unfortunate by products of life.  This course explores a radically positive approach, based on cutting edge integration of attachment theory, trauma treatment and wisdom traditions to Resolving Triggers. The course is designed to provide teaching as well as experiential growth through practices and discussion.
objectiveGoals:
• Increase awareness of what a trigger is and how they happen
  • Improve capacity to slow down the physiological reaction
  • Make step-by-step change in reactivity
  • Compare present moment with past
  • Discover how shame is an attachment wound
  • Contact the 7 Foundational Attachment Needs (Fay, 2015)
name: Resolving Triggers
shortDescription: This program explores a radically positive approach, based on cutting edge integration of attachment theory, trauma treatment and wisdom traditions to Resolving Triggers. The lessons are integrating self-reflection and practice to increase awareness of the topic as well as ways to pivot when triggered by life circumstances.

Program Fee

sessions.title: Why and How We Get Triggered
sessions.description:
Using a Transformational Model designed to teach an integration of attachment theory and yogic psychology we look at triggers as a result of unmet needs.

The Pyramid of Triggers will be introduced to help people see the layers of triggers, creating distinctions in experience.  In addition we’ll use the contemporary practices of self-compassion as a way to mitigate the intensity of affects. 

Participants will be able to:

  • Describe a definition of psychological triggers
  • Learn the 5 Phases of Transformational Attachment Model
  • Identify the three main layers of the Pyramid of Triggers
  • Utilize a body based practice of grounding in the spine

sessions.title: Reactive Cycles and Response Cycles
sessions.description:
By identifying the individual Reactivity Cycle participants develop awareness and ways to slow down that reactivity, increasing their ability to mindfully respond.  They will learn how to track the trigger through their body.  That awareness allows participants choice.  This is especially true as they recognize the thoughts, feelings, and body sensations that propel them into reactivity.  

Participants will be able to:

  • Utilize the power of slowing down reactivity
  • Develop awareness of body sensations and body responses
  • Describe what thoughts and feelings and impulses create the complicated Reactivity Cycle
  • Introduce the Nourishing Opposite as a way to move away from Reactivity 

“After starting with a meditation, Deirdre went deeply into what happens when we enter a Reactive Cycle.  Despite how complicated it can feel to get out of it, Deirdre walked us through, step by step, how to intervene in the process and create a new Response Cycle, one that can be more nourishing and sustaining for living.”

sessions.title: Attunement
sessions.description:
Recognizing the basic anatomy of the brain, how tricky it is especially in dealing with our threat responses, and moving towards soothing –  Our reactivity – for the most part – comes from the triggered signals in our own system, based on the perceptual lens that we see the world through.

The more we orient internally instead of sending our triggered responses externally, looking for the source out there, the less likely we are to fight, create more stress. Attending to ourselves, attuning to our needs allows our systems to ease. Sending feedback loops into our brain that we’re okay.

Participants will be able to:

  • Describe our natural orientation towards threat reactions focused on keeping us safe
  • Practices will involve training the body and mind to slow down
  • Tracking the response cycle to see how its different in nature from Reactive Cycle
  • Apply practices to externalize fears, blocks, resistances, anxieties and worries
  • Utilize interventions into their ongoing psychotherapy practice

sessions.title: Seven Foundational Attachment Needs
sessions.description:
Recognizing how the attachment research of John Bowlby and James Robertson on separation distress is key to understanding the Reactivity Cycle. 

In addition we’ll review the 7 Fundamental Attachment Needs that are native and natural in the development of a self.  Recognizing the Developmental Task of an Adult which is different from the Developmental Task of a Child.

Here we started the exploration of what happens when any of our seven attachment needs are triggered.  Yet, we do not need to despair -- we can repair those needs and build a solid, secure, inner self.

Participants will be able to:

  • Describe the 7 Fundamental Attachment Needs as it shows up in clinical work in particular.
  • Apply the framework of Bowlby and Robertson’s research on separation distress in their own lives and in psychotherapy process.
  • Utilize these perspectives into their ongoing psychotherapy practice
  • Describe the difference of the Developmental Tasks of an Adult from those of a child.

sessions.title: Putting it All Together
sessions.description:
Embodiment of Learnings and program consolidation – Recognizing the benefits of developing a Response Cycle to reduce the intensity of the Reactivity Cycle.

We’ll do this through active engagement with the development of applied interoception. Recognizing the importance of attachment theory in self awareness, self development. 

Participants will be able to:

  • Describe the importance of embodiment in general and interoception, proprioception and sensory awareness in particular, as it relates to everyday life as well as clinical work. 
  • Apply methods to orient themselves and their clients towards mindful embodied awareness of their internal process, and link said awareness to emotional states, towards increased resilience. 
  • Describe the ways a positive approach to resolving triggers allows less compounded triggering.
  • Utilize these perspectives into their ongoing psychotherapy practice

coachInfo.name: Dr Stan Steindl
coachInfo.title: Director of Psychology Consultants Pty Ltd and Adjunct Associate Professor at School of Psychology, University of Queensland

description: The program will help you create a safe space in which to explore both your reservations about change, as well as your motivations to change, and then ultimately arriving at a carefully identified and planned commitment that feels right for you.
marketingDescription:
Behaviour change is difficult! 

All of us can struggle to find the motivation we need to make changes in our lives, even when we know it would be in our own best interests to do so. 

You know the usual suspects: stop smoking or drinking, start exercising or eating healthily. And beyond that there might be chores to do, tasks to complete, or habits to change. 

Or perhaps you feel like it would be a good idea to change how you communicate with your spouse, partner or some other family member or friend. Or your procrastination is really setting in and making it harder for you in your work or study. Or, in fact, it might be time for you to start managing your stress better, or you mood. 

There are many possible changes we could make that would bring us closer to living a good life. But how do we find the motivation to do so?

Motivational Interviewing (MI) is a science-backed approach to helping people discover their own inherent building blocks of motivation. While we can feel very stuck sometimes, the motivation to change is embedded within each and everyone one of us. 

We can stop and reflect: what would I like to change, why would I want to change it, what makes this change truly important to me, and how might I go about it?

In this program, you will work with Dr Stan Steindl, clinical psychologist and experienced therapist and trainer, who will help you create a safe space in which to explore both your reservations about change, as well as your motivations to change, and then ultimately arriving at a carefully identified and planned commitment that feels right for you.

Whether there is just a niggling feeling that perhaps it’s time for something to change, or you know by now that the time has come, this program is meant for you!
objectiveGoals:
• Understand the challenges of behaviour change, including how ambivalence can really make us feel stuck.
  • Become clear about the myths of motivation, especially how we can feel the urge to resist when we are told by someone else what we should change.
  • Start to create a sense of safeness and calmness, and create a sense of partnership with oneself so as to make wise and compassionate choices that are right for you.
  • Arrive at a target behaviour for change, and then start to explore all the arguments against change, and then the arguments for change.
  • Understand and explore the multidimensional nature of motivation, and how these different dimensions might apply to you.
  • Focus specifically on the things that make change important for you, and how can you feel more confident to achieve it.
  • Arrive at a strong commitment to change, one that is important to you and you feel confident to achieve, and then see how you go.
  • From there, you will have a chance to create further plans for the future to increase the chances that your changes will be maintained.
name: Find the motivation to make the changes that are right for you!
shortDescription: This program will help you create a safe space in which to explore both your reservations about change, as well as your motivations to change, and then ultimately arriving at a carefully identified and planned commitment that feels right for you.

coachInfo.name: Tara Deliberto, PhD
coachInfo.title: Founder and Director of Integrated Treatment LLC,  author of Treating Eating Disorders in Adolescents, consultant at Equip Health, founder and former director of New York Presbyterian Hospital’s Eating Disorders Partial Hospitalization Program, former assistant professor at Weill Cornell Medicine

description:
This program, Feel Good about Your Body, is for anyone who struggles with body image and having a healthy relationship to food. 

In this program, we will begin by critically examining our own ideals about bodies such as “being thin” or “being fit,” and how these ideals developed.
marketingDescription:
This program, Feel Good about Your Body, is for anyone who struggles with body image and having a healthy relationship to food. 

In this program, we will begin by critically examining our own ideals about bodies such as “being thin” or “being fit,” and how these ideals developed.

Digging deeper, we will then investigate the specific fears we each have about not living up to these ideals (e.g., such as being rejected or mocked for looking a certain way, being unhealthy, etc.). 

After developing an understanding of our ideals and fears, we will take a good hard look at our unhealthy behaviors and how they are influenced by our internal world.

The program will conclude with the development of individualized plans to challenge toxic ideals and confront fears through changing our behavior. In this way, the ultimate aim is to help you to compassionately reclaim your own inherent power.
objectiveGoals:
1. Examine our internalized ideals about bodies (e.g. being thin, muscular, fit, etc.) that fuel an unhealthy relationship to the body
  2. Examine our fears related to not meeting these ideals (e.g., “if I eat this food, I will be fat and will be rejected” etc.)
  3. Develop an understanding of unhealthy body image behaviors (e.g., frequently weighing oneself, hiding one’s body with baggy clothes, compulsive exercise, etc.)
  4. Develop an understanding of unhealthy eating behaviors (e.g., going on a juice cleanse to quickly lose weight, etc.)
  5. Learn how to use mindfulness and acceptance practices to overcome fears related to not meeting body ideals
  6. Develop a plan for living life in accordance with compassion-based ideals (e.g., loving oneself) that foster a healthy relationship with your body
  7. Foster a compassionate relationship to your body through the challenging of ideals, confrontation of fears, and engaging in healthy behavior
name: Feel Good about Your Body
shortDescription: This program will help you create a safe space in which to explore both your reservations about change, as well as your motivations to change, and then ultimately arriving at a carefully identified and planned commitment that feels right for you.
modulesOverview: This program is delivered in 6 sessions according to the following schedule:
scheduled: 2 hour/week (approx) for 6 weeks
self_paced:
30 mins/week (approx)

  • Live video lectures
schedule_communicate: During the program, clients can communicate via private messaging with the members of their cohort and the coaching team.

sessions.title: Internalized Ideals
sessions.description:
• Welcome to the program
  • Goals of program
  • Discussion of ideals:
    • What ideals are
    • How they develop through messaging and reinforcement:
      • Societal/cultural level (e.g., thinness is good)
      • Social circle level (e.g., “you look great for losing weight!”)
      • Individual experience level (e.g., feeling pride when losing weight)
    • Psychological impact of ideals
    • The unmindful acceptance of ideals
    • Mindfully examining ideals
    • Pros and cons of ideals
    • Reconsidering ideals
  • Alternative ideals
    • Loving oneself
    • Telling the truth
    • Acceptance
    • Service
    • Non-judgment
    • Compassion
  • HW: list out ideals, where they came from, and if you want to have them

sessions.title: Fears
sessions.description:
• Preparing for this session
    • It could be triggering
    • Take breaks as needed
    • Square breathing practice
    • Grounding practice (looking around the room, naming objects, etc.)
  • Fears about body size / shape / weight
  • Relation of fears to ideals
  • What are your fears? 
    • Abandonment
    • Rejection
    • Failure
    • Being a target of abuse/bullying
    • Safety
    • Gender dysphoria
  • Experience of fear:
    • How intensely do you experience fear?
    • How much do you want to avoid it?
    • How much do you avoid it?
    • How do you avoid it?
  • Start thinking about how to confront these fears
  • HW: rate fears on the “fear list” on a 0-10 scale, with ten being the most fear

sessions.title: Body Image Behaviors
sessions.description:
• What are behaviors?span>
  • Connecting ideals, thoughts, fears, and body image behaviors
  • Discussion of experiential avoidance
    • “Negative reinforcement”
    • Understanding the importance of experiential avoidance
  • Ego-syntonic v.s. ego-dystonic behaviors
  • Deciding to change behavior
  • List of body image behaviors (e.g., checking, avoidance, etc.)
  • Plan to change body image behaviors
  • HW: engage in one healthy body image behavior this week

sessions.title: Eating Behaviors
sessions.description:
• Connecting ideals, thoughts, fears, and eating behaviors
  • Discussion of experiential avoidance with eating behaviors
  • Quick Review of ego-syntonic v.s. ego-dystonic behaviors
  • Deciding to change behavior
  • List of eating behaviors (e.g., dieting, restricting, avoiding food, etc.)
  • Plan to change eating behaviors
  • HW: engage in one recovery eating behavior this week

sessions.title: Fears and Compassion
sessions.description:
• Discuss the facing of fears.
  • Recall a time you're faced your fear. What happened?
  • What’s the worst that can happen? Is it worse than living with a bad relationship with food and your body? That’s the choice!
  • Confronting feared situations.
  • Comparisons with others.
  • Feeling connected again.
  • Barriers to Compassion.
  • Understanding and compassion.
  • Compassion exercises:
    • CFT exercise imagining the mistreated animal
    • Discussion of apology letter to self and others
  • HW: imaginal exposure (if fear is below an 8) and/or apology letter.

sessions.title: Continued Plan
sessions.description:
• Gratitude for the body.
  • Gratitude for food.
  • Building rituals around food. 
  • Plan for decreasing a psychologically unhealthy body and eating behaviors through the challenging of ideals and confrontation of fear.
  • HW: Enact the plan!

overview:
• 6 Week Program with weekly session
  • Live Sessions are facilitated
